messages: 155a38de57ee586fdcb8511ddf2c344b (02:00): Xgc: ok let me look again
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:00): sanguis: You probably need to think about ordering the set better.
98cf6e709c570b79ebf8fbd2f15900d4 (02:00): archivist: hm.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:00): sanguis: Right now your result is based on badly defined behavior in the order in which the records are returned.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:01): sanguis: If the records you care about are in the first 30, you're happy.  But that's just an accident unless you order the set.
98cf6e709c570b79ebf8fbd2f15900d4 (02:01): archivist: I heard that that bug had been already fixed in some mysql versions
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:02): Jivedue: I would, but I still don't know what he means by "it works".

155a38de57ee586fdcb8511ddf2c344b (02:04): Xgc: the limit was there because I have been testing in php my admin and it adds that to the code, that I grabbed for better line numbers, I got rid of it, and I also commented out line ( it worked great
9ce30ddf0128522375f75b49afaffeee (02:04): Xgc: haha, I hope you know I'm only teasing

d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:06): sanguis: Line 9 only removes some lines from the result.  It doesn't change any of the other results.  The calculations are identical between those queries.  Maybe it would help if you defined what you mean by "doesn't work" and "does work".
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:08): sanguis: Also note that if you really need that LEFT JOIN, your WHERE clause is not appropriate.

155a38de57ee586fdcb8511ddf2c344b (02:08): what I mean by 'it works' is that the math is being done properly. say a orders.products_price = 0 and products_orders.products_price = 5 and the quanity is a constant 1. then amount should according to this query equal 5 right? (5*1=5)
155a38de57ee586fdcb8511ddf2c344b (02:09): well as soon as I un comment the time stamp lines I am getting a result of 0
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:09): sanguis: The calculation is correct.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:09): sanguis: That's certainly not the issue.

d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:10): sanguis: I suspect you may be talking about the LEFT JOIN behavior that you break when adding those right table tests in the WHERE clause.  You probably need to move them to the ON clause.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:10): sanguis: Test for equality in orders and customers are not appropriate in the WHERE clause.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:11): sanguis: Otherwise, you'd have used an INNER JOIN.
d923d906582234f7da470514434fab8b (02:12): sanguis: Export some data ni the form of INSERT statements, along with the create table statements so that your test results can be duplicated.
155a38de57ee586fdcb8511ddf2c344b (02:12): exporting

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:37): hello all... need some advice about how to best organize a peice of my database:  We have equipment installed at a number of locations, each location has a primary contact, and any number of secondary contacts... all contacts can be either a primary or secondary contact at multiple locations.  How would I represent this best in my database?
ab14bd2ee3f91af24d7bbf48a933b8f9 (02:39): shwag, higher, it means the index has fewer duplicates so easier to find the req data
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:39): Con-fuze-ed: Three tables: locations (locationId, name), contacts (contactId, name), locationContactMap (locationId, contactId, maybe contactType)
da913d55163d6c36fdd222ec607ed9db (02:39): hello
da913d55163d6c36fdd222ec607ed9db (02:40): i have recovered a table with REPAIR TABLE after a crash, but how can i check quickly if there is some errors in the other tables plz? (i have 500 tables)

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:40): snoyes: thought of that... locations-contacts... if the contact is primary for that location I could flag it in the intermediate table... however, how do I prevent a location from getting multiple primaries (other than careful frontend coding)
39f7e0e92afea8e80951b6bf030c3545 (02:40): archivist, shouldnt is be like     cardinality /  count(*)

07e3d1d1f6b0e341e949da380971caa0 (02:41): Anyone here use Mysql's Date functions much? I was wonder if there was a easy way to use TO_DAYS() and paypals horrid date syntax without reformting in another language.
42e4f03c62cbdf45eaef2bde88ebcf48 (02:41): Cald, tried just typing repair table; without any parameters?
da913d55163d6c36fdd222ec607ed9db (02:42): doesnt work

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:42): stabbby: there are some very powerful formatting functions you can use in mysql's query language... you may need to do a pretty long query, but you can reformat the data almost anyway you like.
07e3d1d1f6b0e341e949da380971caa0 (02:43): Con-fuze-ed: alright I'll dig deeper into the docs thanks
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:43): Con-fuze-ed: With a trigger - if the location already has a primary, set the newly created one to secondary.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:44): alternatively, make the contactType nullable, and set it to 1 for primary, null for secondary, and create a unique index on (locationId, contactType)

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:44): stabbby: look at the string formatting functions... you could have the date function export the date as YYYY-MM-DD then use Left to extract the peices and present the data anyway you like
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:44): then adding another 1 will result in a unique key failure, but you can add all the nulls you want.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:45): It's a hack, and if you tell anyone I told you, I'll deny it.
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:45): snoyes: why would you consider it a hack... sounds like an elegent solution to me?
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:46): Because you're using null for a known value.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:46): and null is, by definition, unknown.
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:46): I'm not too comfortable with triggers... any chance you have a good resource for explaining that method
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:47): one other alternative is to keep the contactId of the primary in the locations table, and make this other map for secondary contacts only.
39f7e0e92afea8e80951b6bf030c3545 (02:47): how do I convert a column from DATETIME to DATE
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:47): shwag: You want to conver the column in the table, or just select the date portion of the column in some query?
39f7e0e92afea8e80951b6bf030c3545 (02:48): snoyes, convert the table. i think it will speed things up since I only use date and not the time anyways.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:48): ALTER TABLE tableName MODIFY COLUMN theColumn DATE;
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:49): Con-fuze-ed: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.0/en/create-trigger.html

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:49): snoyes: that was what I was about to do... the only problem I had with that is that on the locations table, the feild would be primarycontactid and it would relate to contactid on the contacts table... I really hate to have a FK with a name change
da913d55163d6c36fdd222ec607ed9db (02:49): i have to use myisamchk, but i with a php script its ok
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:50): well, just name the constraint as contactId, and clench your teerth.
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:50): yeah... it just makes things more confuzing for the developer who follows behind me.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:51): and don't forget that you can leave comments in the field definition.
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:52): true that.... thanks... I guess simple is better... that solution can't be worse than using triggers ;-)

3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:52): I think I'd stick with the primaryContact in the locations table, and the others in another table. Maintains the normal approaches for one to many and many to many relationships.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:53): You'll have to decide if you'll also list the primary contact in the contactMap.

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:53): yeah... just thought of one disadvantage... if I want to list all locations that a contact is associated with, I need to do two queries... one on the intermediate table and one on the locations table.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:53): yeah, that would be a reason to put the primaries also in the contactMap
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:54): I'd even argue that isn't really denormalization, because being a contact and being primaryContact are two different relationships.

f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:55): but then I need to write code in the frontend to make sure the contactMap table has record of their primary locations.  I think I need to have a cigarette and think on that some more
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:55): perhaps I'll just create a second map table
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:55): one for primaries (with unique location) and one for all (many to many)
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:55): I'd say the contactMap doesn't need to know anything about the primaries.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:56): and the locations table can store the primaryContact, since it's one to many.
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:56): of course I'd still need two queries
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:56): To do what?
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:57): yep... either way... I'm doing two queries to list all locations a contact is associated with... one query on the map and one on the locations table.
3d825ab736200154c06f95be2c1fdd8b (02:57): not if the primary is also listed in the map.
f64420bc5fa8f3db0500196367a772a4 (02:57): true... but to flag if they are the primary I would
